dilemmas.name: Trolley problem (original)
dilemmas.description: There is a runaway trolley barreling down the railway tracks. Ahead, on the tracks, there are five people tied up and unable to move. The trolley is headed straight for them. You are standing some distance off in the train yard, next to a lever. If you pull this lever, the trolley will switch to a different set of tracks. However, you notice that there is one person tied up on the side track.

sentiments.description: More humans are more valuable than less humans

dilemmas.name: Trolley problem (fat man)
dilemmas.description: As before, a trolley is hurtling down a track towards five people. You are on a bridge under which it will pass, and you can stop it by putting something very heavy in front of it. As it happens, there is a very fat man next to you â€“ your only way to stop the trolley is to push him over the bridge and onto the track, killing him to save five. Should you proceed?

sentiments.description: Killing someone as a means to an end is worse than letting 5 persons die

dilemmas.name: Trolley problem (fat villain)
dilemmas.description: The further development of this example involves the case, where the fat man is, in fact, the villain who put these five people in peril. In this instance, pushing the villain to his death, especially to save five innocent people, seems not only morally justifiable but perhaps even imperative

dilemmas.name: Eating animals
dilemmas.description: There is a living animal. You can decide to have it killed and served to you as food

dilemmas.name: Murderer ask question
dilemmas.description: You know the location of some persons. A murderer is about to go to that location to kill the person. You can save the person by telling the murderer that the person is some place else.

dilemmas.name: Utility monster
dilemmas.description: You have 1 million dollars. You can either divide them equally between 10 persons or give it all to one of them. That one person in special in such a way that he will be 100 times more happy than the other per dollar.

dilemmas.name: Mere addition paradox (Original)
dilemmas.description: Imagine a country of 1 million people. Every person currently have a happiness level of 1 per year. You have the choice to put in place policies that will increase the population to 20 million but the happiness per person will decrease to 0.1 per year.

dilemmas.name: The violinist
dilemmas.description: You wake up in the morning and find yourself back to back in bed with an unconscious violinist. A famous unconscious violinist. He has been found to have a fatal kidney ailment, and the Society of Music Lovers has canvassed all the available medical records and found that you alone have the right blood type to help. They have therefore kidnapped you, and last night the violinist's circulatory system was plugged into yours, so that your kidneys can be used to extract poisons from his blood as well as your own. [If he is unplugged from you now, he will die; but] in nine months he will have recovered from his ailment, and can safely be unplugged from you.

dilemmas.name: Robbin' Hood
dilemmas.description: You are poor with no money to give. You have the opportunity to successfully rob a bank and give the money to the needy.

dilemmas.name: A Doctor's Dilemma
dilemmas.description: You are a doctor at a top hospital. You have six gravely ill patients, five of whom are in urgent need of organ transplants. You can't help them, though, because there are no available organs that can be used to save their lives. The sixth patient, however, will die without a particular medicine. If s/he dies, you will be able to save the other five patients by using the organs of patient 6, who is an organ donor.

sentiments.description: Killing someone as a means to an end is worse than letting 5 persons die

dilemmas.name: Send criminals to paradise
dilemmas.description: You have 10 criminals that have committed the most heinous crimes. You have a choice to send them to paradise instead of prison.

dilemmas.name: Death sentence
dilemmas.description: You are the leader of your country. You get to decide if death sentence should be practiced for the most horrific crimes.

effects.explanation: This might reduce crime and save 10 lives
This might normalize murder and lead to 10 more murders

dilemmas.name: Progressive tax
dilemmas.description: You are the leader of an fictional country. You get to decide if progressive tax should be implemented. The total amount of taxes is fixed, so that the mean is the same.

effects.explanation: This might increase happiness since it might lead to higher material wealth among the poor.
This might decrease happiness since it might lead to lower material wealth among the rich.
This might increase happiness among the rich since it might lead to fewer beggers wich some rich people don't like to see.
This might lead to increased inequallity which might result in a bloody revolution where people loses their heads.
This might lead to doctors working less and thus saving fewer lives.
This might lead to people working less and thus producing less goods that makes people happy.

Mere addition paradox (Human life)

dilemmas.name: Punishment
dilemmas.description: You have a person who has committed the most heinous crimes. You can punish the person by inflicting him pain before letting him go, but it will not change his behavoir.
